title: Hong Kong's leader Carrie Lam warns of Beijing's military intervene for the first time
text:
Hong Kong's leader Carrie Lam warned today that the Chinese military could step in if an uprising for democratic reforms that has rocked the city for months 'becomes so bad', but reiterated the government still hopes to resolve the crisis itself.

Lam urged foreign critics to accept that the four months of protests marked by escalating violence were no longer 'a peaceful movement for democracy'.

Beijing's army stationed in the city gave its first warning to activists on Sunday, telling them that they could be arrested for targeting its barracks with lasers.

Hong Kong's Chief Executive Carrie Lam has warned of Beijing's military intervention if the city's anti-government chaos continues. The financial hub has been rocked by four months of pro-democracy street demonstrations involving escalating violence from activists and police

Lam's remarks came after experts claimed that China had quietly doubled its troop levels in the semi-autonomous city with a so-called routine 'rotation'. Pictured, Chinese soldiers People's Liberation Army (PLA) show off their military might in Hong Kong on June 30

Lam (pictured) reiterated today that her government still hopes to resolve the crisis itself

Lam's remarks came after Asian and Western envoys last month claimed that China had quietly doubled its troop levels in the semi-autonomous city by sending over extra soldiers in August in a so-called 'routine rotation'.

Previous satellite pictures also showed that China mobilised in August hundreds of military vehicles and more than 10,000 paramilitary police officers to Shenzhen, a city bordering Hong Kong.

Chinese military also issued warning that they could hit Hong Kong 'in 10 minutes' and carried out multiple live-fire anti-riot drills in Shenzhen in warning to pro-democracy protesters.

A People's Liberation Army soldier holds a banner to warn protesters on Sunday during a rally against the mask ban, the first interaction between Beijing's troops and Hong Kong activists

Armored personnel carriers of China's People's Liberation Army (PLA) pass through the Huanggang Port border between Chinese mainland and Hong Kong on August 29

China accuses Hong Kong's last British governor of being 'cold-blooded' China has called Chris Patten, the last British governor of Hong Kong, of being 'cold-blooded' after Mr Patten billed the new mask ban in Hong Kong as 'absolutely madness'. Hong Kong's leader Carrie Lam on Friday invoked a colonial-era emergency law introduced by Britain to pass the legislation. Speaking to Sky News, Mr Patten said Lam 'would have to be crazy to be making these decisions on her own'. He also warned that 'people are going to get killed' in the increasingly violent unrest. Mr Patten should 'look at himself in the mirror' and reflect about his remarks, said the Office of the Commissioner of China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Hong Kong. The Office said Mr Patten ignored the fact that Britain was a forerunner in using the anti-mask law in the London Riots in 2011. '[His comments] completely exposed his true colour of being hypocritical, stubborn and cold-blooded,' the Office said. 'We again urge Chris Patten to immediately withdraw his black hand and stop meddling in Hong Kong affairs, stop harming Hong Kong with evil deals and stop doomsday craziness.'

Lam said seeking Chinese intervention was provided for under Hong Kong's constitution, but that she cannot reveal under what circumstances she will do so.

'I still strongly feel that we should find the solutions ourselves.

'That is also the position of the central government that Hong Kong should tackle the problem on her own but if the situation becomes so bad, then no options could be ruled out if we want Hong Kong to at least have another chance,' she told a news conference.

The protests started in June over a now-shelved extradition bill that would have allowed some criminal suspects to be sent to mainland China for trial but have since morphed into a larger anti-government movement.

Protesters say the bill is an example of Beijing's increasing influence over the former British colony, which was promised a high level of autonomy when it returned to Chinese rule in 1997.

The unrest has pummeled tourism and hurt businesses in the global financial hub, further bruising the city's economy as it grapples with effects of the US-China trade war.

President Donald Trump on Monday urged Chinese President Xi Jinping to ensure a 'humane solution' in Hong Kong. He warned that any 'bad' outcome could hurt trade talks ahead of negotiations in Washington on Thursday.

Hardening her government's stance on the protests last week, Lam invoked a colonial-era emergency law to criminalise the wearing of masks at rallies.

But the move fueled more anger, with continuous daily violence over the long holiday weekend.

The PLA has maintained a garrison in Hong Kong since the former British colony was returned to China in 1997. This general view shows the PLA Forces Hong Kong Building

A satellite image shows military and security vehicles parked in a stadium in Shenzhen

Chinese servicemen attend a crowd control exercise at the Shenzhen Bay Sports Center in Shenzhen across the bay from Hong Kong on August 16. One of the soldiers is seen carrying a huge fork, which may also be electric, to be used in crowd control during a staged clash

China stops showing NBA basketball games over democracy row Chinese state broadcaster CCTV will no longer air two NBA pre-season games set to be played in the country, the station said today. CCTV indicated the decision was prompted by NBA Commissioner Adam Silver's remarks in Japan following a tweet by Houston Rockets general manager Daryl Morey last week that supported anti-government demonstrations in Hong Kong. 'We're strongly dissatisfied and oppose Adam Silver's claim to support Morey's right to freedom of expression,' CCTV said. 'We believe that any remarks that challenge national sovereignty and social stability are not within the scope of freedom of speech.' Morey apologised on Monday for the tweet he swiftly deleted on the weekend. His initial tweet included an image captioned: 'Fight For Freedom. Stand With Hong Kong.'

The city was nearly paralysed after masked activists hurled petrol bombs at police, smashed metro stations and vandalised businesses with links to mainland China.

Police arrested 14 men and 12 women aged between 13 and 33 during Sunday's chaos. Police said they would be charged with one account of rioting.

Police also said 14 of them, six men and eight women, would also be charged with violating the anti-mask law, which carries prison terms of up to one year, reported HK01.com.

An 18-year-old student and a 38-year-old woman were the first people to be charged with the new legislation.

Police officers last week fired gunshots while under attack from protesters, wounding two teenagers aged 14 and 18 who were the first victims of police gunfire since the protests started.

Enforcement of the mask ban began Saturday, and Lam said it was too early to call it a failure.

Critics fear the emergency law, which gives Lam broad powers to implement any measures she deems necessary, could pave the way for more draconian moves.

A group of masked protesters smash up Wong Tai Sin station in Kowloon on Monday. The city's metro system was shut down on Saturday after activists broke into and thrashed stations.

Journalists run after being hit by petrol bombs hurled by protesters during clashed with police in Wan Chai on October 6. The city was plunged into further chaos at the weekend after Lam invoked a colonial-era emergency law to criminalise the wearing of masks at rallies

Protesters are arrested by police during a clash at a rally in Wan Chai district on Sunday

Sixteen people are charged for wearing face masks Sixteen people in Hong Kong have been charged for covering their faces during demonstrations. An 18-year-old student and a 38-year-old woman were the first to face charges yesterday after the legislation took effect on Saturday. Fourteen more people, six men and eight women, are due to appear in court today after being arrested during clashed on Sunday, police said.

Lam said the government would make 'careful assessment' before imposing other measures under the law, such as internet controls.

She also pledged to continue dialogue and take steps to address livelihood and economic problems in a policy address due October 16 when the Legislative Council resumes.

Protesters stormed and damaged the legislative building on July 1, requiring repairs. Lam appealed for peace when the legislative session reopens, warning that further disruptions would set back the approval of bills and impede the city's development.

Footage shows a police officer drawing his gun and shooting an 18-year-old protester

A protester wears a Guy Fawkes mask in defiance of the new law banning activists from covering their faces during a standoff with police in Mong Kok on October 7

The city's subway and trains, that carry some five million passengers daily, mostly reopened Tuesday but will shut early amid fear of more protests.

The entire MTR network was shut down Saturday, with limited services the last two days.

Footage from RTHK shows a group of black-clad protesters thrashing a train bound for mainland China with hammers and steel bars on Friday - the first time a train carriage had been attacked.

Students from La Salle College wear masks, which have been banned at protests under emergency powers, as they walk to school in Hong Kong on October 8

The city's metro system, which carries some five million people daily, was entirely shut on Saturday after many stations had been stormed and smashed. Pictured, a woman looks at a vandalised metro station entrance that remains closed in Causeway Bay district on October 8

Protesters also threw objects on the rail track as the train pulled away.

An MTR spokesman, who identified himself only as Terry, confirmed the incident and said some cross-border services have been suspended Tuesday.

Scores of students wore masks in defiance as they returned to school.

Some rallied at lunchtime, chanting slogans and holding placards that read 'You may take away my mask but not my belief' and 'Ideas are bullet-proof'.
description: Hong Kong's leader Carrie Lam warned today that the Chinese military could step in if the uprising for democratic reforms that has rocked the city for months 'becomes so bad'.
